justification: The authors state: “To verify whether the stress induction procedure was successful, we measured subjective ratings, salivary cortisol levels, and blood pressure,” describing salivary cortisol as an objective index of stress.

In the same verification section, they add: “To measure blood pressure, we placed an arm cuff … A continuous blood pressure measure was taken,” indicating blood‐pressure values were used to quantify stress responses.

After the SECPT the paper notes: “Participants indicated on a scale from 0 ('not at all') to 100 ('very much') how stressful… they experienced the previous situation,” showing subjective stress was gauged with this rating.
The same item set asked how ‘painful’ the situation was on the 0–100 scale, making this scale the instrument for perceived painfulness.
Participants also rated how ‘unpleasant’ the situation was on the identical 0–100 continuum, operationalising subjective unpleasantness.
Under ‘Desire ratings’ the authors say: “Participants reported how much they would like to consume each liquid … on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much),” defining the measure of desire.
For hunger they write: “Participants reported their hunger on a scale from 0 (not hungry at all) to 100 (very hungry),” explicitly linking the construct to the scale used.

The paper explains: “Explicit response-outcome knowledge was assessed with multiple-choice questions. Participants were asked … which symbol they had to select … and where the symbol was positioned,” identifying the questionnaire as the measurement tool.
